title: 104_hr892
content: The "Independent Counsel Accountability and Reform Act of 1995" amends Section 599 of title 28, United States Code, by replacing "Reauthorization Act of 1994" with "Accountability and Reform Act of 1995". It also establishes the basis for preliminary investigations. The "Independent Counsel Accountability and Reform Act of 1995" amends Section 591 of title 28, United States Code, by specifying that specific information from a credible source must be received within 15 days to determine the need for a preliminary investigation. The "Independent Counsel Accountability and Reform Act of 1995" requires the Attorney General to determine the need for a preliminary investigation within 15 days of receiving specific information from a credible source regarding a potential violation of Federal criminal law. If there is insufficient evidence, the matter is closed; if there is sufficient evidence, a preliminary investigation is commenced. If the determination cannot be made within the 15-day period, a preliminary investigation is still initiated. The "Independent Counsel Accountability and Reform Act of 1995" mandates the Attorney General to start a preliminary investigation within 15 days upon receiving specific credible information about a potential Federal criminal law violation. Additional information received must be specific and from a credible source. SEC. 4. PROSECUTORIAL JURISDICTION OF INDEPENDENT COUNSEL. Prosecutorial jurisdiction of independent counsel under title 28, United States Code, is amended to specify limitations to alleged criminal law violations and related matters. The independent counsel is granted authority to fully investigate and prosecute within defined prosecutorial jurisdiction. The court ensures the independent counsel has authority to investigate and prosecute alleged criminal law violations, including perjury and obstruction of justice. Amendments specify the scope of prosecutorial jurisdiction for the independent counsel. SEC. 5. AUTHORITIES AND DUTIES OF INDEPENDENT COUNSEL. The text discusses amendments to office space provisions for independent counsels and compliance with Department of Justice policies regarding criminal laws and information release. The text discusses amendments to the enforcement of criminal laws and the release of information relating to criminal proceedings, as well as limitations on expenditures for independent counsel offices. SEC. 6. REMOVAL, TERMINATION, AND PERIODIC REAPPOINTMENT OF INDEPENDENT COUNSEL. Section 596(a)(1) of title 28, United States Code, is amended to allow removal of independent counsel for failure to comply with Department of Justice policies. Section 596(b)(2) is amended to allow termination of an independent counsel office by the court under certain conditions. The independent counsel can be removed if the investigation is completed or not in the public interest. Monthly expenditures must be reported to specified committees. The independent counsel must report monthly expenditures to designated committees. Reappointment of the counsel is required every two years or at the end of each subsequent two-year period, subject to court evaluation for termination. The court must evaluate whether to terminate the office of the independent counsel before reappointing the current applicant or selecting a new qualified person within 90 days if no action is taken. The Comptroller General of the United States will submit a report to Congress within 1 year of the enactment of this Act, with recommendations to improve cost controls for independent counsel offices under chapter 40 of title 28, United States Code.
